title: 110_hr5793
content: The "Cell Tax Fairness Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It includes a moratorium provision. The "Cell Tax Fairness Act of 2008" prohibits new discriminatory taxes on mobile services, providers, or property for 5 years. Mobile service is defined as commercial mobile radio service or any service intended for mobile phones. Mobile service property includes all property used by providers for mobile services. The "Cell Tax Fairness Act of 2008" prohibits new discriminatory taxes on mobile services for 5 years. Mobile service providers are defined as entities selling or providing mobile services. New discriminatory tax refers to taxes imposed by State or local jurisdictions on mobile services. The "Cell Tax Fairness Act of 2008" prohibits discriminatory taxes on mobile services for 5 years, ensuring that mobile service providers are not unfairly taxed compared to other businesses or property. The term "State or local jurisdiction" refers to any State, the District of Columbia, territories, political subdivisions, or any governmental entity acting on their behalf. It excludes public utility property regulated by State or Federal authorities and mobile services not previously taxed before the Act's enactment. The term "tax" refers to any charge imposed by a governmental entity for generating revenues, excluding fees for specific privileges or benefits. The term "tax" refers to any charge imposed by a governmental entity for generating revenues, excluding fees for specific privileges or benefits. Section 254 of the Communications Act of 1934 authorizes taxes for E-911 communications systems. Rules of construction determine if a tax is discriminatory based on various factors. The Railroad Revitalization and Regulatory Reform Act of 1976 outlines exclusions for specific taxes, industries, and property types. The term "new discriminatory tax" does not include taxes on mobile services if they replace existing ones. The new tax or modification should not generate more revenue than the tax it replaces for mobile services, providers, or property. SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT. The burden of proof in any proceeding brought under this Act shall be upon the party seeking relief and shall be by a preponderance of the evidence on all issues of fact. In granting relief against a discriminatory or excessive tax under this Act, the court shall prevent, restrain, or terminate the imposition, levy, or collection of the discriminatory or excessive portion of the tax as determined by the court.
